“ Prosper z—An Ecclesiastical writer of the fifth century, of great excel- lence and eminence, and who at that early period ably opposed the Pelagian heresy: he died about the year 463. There is an edition of his works in 8vo. so recent as the year 1732.

† Clemens Alexandrinus :—a distinguished Father who lived in the third century. He was employed as a Catoehist, and afterwards made a Presby. ter in the church of Alexandria. Under him arose many eminent meng though, from the manner in which his mind was evidently imbued and warped by the mystical philosophy of his time (in which he had acquired an extensive knowledge, as any of his writings would shew)‚ his statements of Christian doctrine were defective. He was a copious writer; but of all his works only the following appear to remain, viz. his “ Proetrepticon, or an Exhortation to the Pagans;” “ Pedagogus‚ or the 1nstructor;'’ the ,fragment of a treatise on the use of richeS‚ entitled‚ “ What rich man can be saved ?'’ and his “ Stromata‚” the work cited above by our Expositor.
